participants.participant: Peter Sands, Group Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Well, good morning, London, and good afternoon to those of you in Hong Kong and India. I'm delighted to report that 2010 was the 8th consecutive year of record income and profits. And this performance once again demonstrates our ability to deliver substantial and sustained value for our shareholders.

Standard Chartered continues to perform strongly, delivering a 19% increase in profits and earnings per share rise of 14% and a return on equity of over 14%. We enter 2011 in excellent shape with strong growth momentum. In a few minutes, Richard will take you through today's results in more detail and then Peter will outline where we see further opportunities to grow the business in the coming years. But first there are a number of things I would like to highlight.

Starting with shareholder value, as a board focus on long term value creation for our shareholders is a key priority. Our investment in the business for the long term and strengthening of our already strong balance sheet, while simultaneously increasing income and growing earnings, reflects the strong and continued success of our business model.

We are again increasing the total amount of dividend paid to shareholders. The board is recommending a final dividend of $0.4665 per share, making a total annual dividend on a post-rights basis of $0.6915 per share, which is up 9%. For the many shareholders who participated in last October's rights issue the total dividend received is up 15% on the 2009 dividend payment.

In June we successfully listed our Indian depository receipts on the Bombay and National Stock Exchanges in India. Later in the year, our investors helped us to raise over $5 billion on our rights issue and I would like to thank our investors for their continued support and for the confidence they've shown in our future.

Remuneration. Our approach to remuneration is both simple and consistent. At Standard Chartered we reward our staff for performance and not for failure. Against a profit increase of 19% and an increase in our staff numbers of around 9%, our bonus pool costs have increased modestly on the 2009 levels. We remain satisfied that our remuneration policies encourage long-term performance rather than short-term risk taking, and we continue to meet the significantly enhanced remuneration codes of both the FSA and FSB whilst assuring that our rewards remain competitive.

The political and regulatory debate on remuneration, principally in the E.U., and to a lesser extent in the U.S., is just one of the many external uncertainties we face today, and while we fully support the need for reform of the financial sector, as a board, we are deeply concerned about the amount of regulatory change being thrust upon us and with the prospect of significantly more change still to come. A great deal has been done since the start of the financial crisis to strengthen bank balance sheets and to better manage risk, but if we continue along the path of demanding that banks hold more capital and liquidity, pay more in taxes and ring-fence some perceived riskier activities without international coordination and alignment, then this could severely limit the banking industry's ability to support economic recovery and create new jobs.

But let's not today dwell on regulation. I'm delighted that in summary 2010 was another year of strong performance for Standard Chartered, despite unprecedented levels of external flux. The bank is in great shape, and we have again demonstrated that we have the right strategy, the right culture, and the right geographical footprint to deliver consistent and sustained value for our shareholders. Let me now ask Richard to walk you through the numbers. Richard?

Thank you, John. Good afternoon, Hong Kong and India, and good morning, London. 2010 has been another year of delivery for the group with an unbroken trend of record profit and income growth now stretching back to 2003. This strong performance is built on multiple and diverse income engines, high levels of investment as loan impairment fell, a robust balance sheet with excellent footings growth, underpinning strong activity levels, that we have seen some margin compression and higher competition. We have delivered record levels of profit over previous record levels. This is not a recovery story. Let me draw out some key highlights.

Record levels of income, over $16 billion, and a profit, as guided, of over $6.1 billion. We've continued our record of consistent delivery; over the past eight years income has grown at a compound annual growth rate of 17% and profit at 22%. Income is well diversified with 23 markets contributing over $100 million of income, up from 19 markets three years ago. Costs up 13%, as we have deliberately invested in both businesses to underpin future income momentum. This decision to invest was enabled by continued improvement in the risk environment with loan impairment falling sharply in both businesses. Strong operating profit growth of 19%.

A significantly strengthened capital position with core tier one at 11.8%, built from a combination of strong organic equity generation and the recent rights issue. We've also managed risk weighted asset or RWA well, growing by 15% in the year. Our balance sheet remains well diversified. Liquidity and funding, we've attracted an incremental $60 billion of customer deposits during 2010. Our A-D ratio remains conservative at 77.9%; our liquid asset ratio has strengthened further to 26.6%. Our consistent performance and balance sheet resilience have been recognized by both Moody's and Fitch, who upgraded our credit rating to A1 and AA- respectively during 2010.

Let me take you through the numbers. At a group level, income is up 6%, good growth in consumer banking income, up 8%, and wholesale banking Client Income up 17%, has been partly offset by weaker Own Account income, following the extraordinary conditions in the early part of 2009. Net interest income is up 11%, reflecting very strong customer loan and customer deposit growth, up 22% and 23% respectively, partially offset by margin compression.

Non-Funded Income is broadly flat with fee income up an excellent 26% driven by Wealth Management, Corporate Finance and Trade, but offset by decreases in Trading income and in other operating income. Before I talk about expenses, you can see that loan impairment was down 56% on 2009, reflecting the improvement in the risk environment. Operating profit of $6.122 billion is up 19%.

Expenses. The year-on-year growth in expenses of 13% has been driven by a number of items. Our investment program, which we accelerated in the second half of 2009 and then took a deliberate decision to continue throughout 2010, accounts for some 40% of the cost increase. An increase in the business as usual cost base, reflecting amongst other things inflation in salaries, accounts for around a third of the cost delta.

The impact of FX on the cost base accounts for just over 20% of the increase and we've also incurred incremental direct regulatory and compliance costs of over $150 million, given investment in upgrading capabilities, systems infrastructure, such as rolling out further sophisticated anti-money laundering and trade surveillance systems, new reporting mechanisms required by all the new regulations, for example, liquidity, and significant expenditure incurred in specific reviews from earlier detailed review of historical sanctions compliance across various geographies.

You should also bear in mind that there was an offset to the items I've just mentioned of some $120 million and this predominately arose from the non-recurrence of the charge in the prior year relating to the repurchase of structured notes in Taiwan, but was partly offset by a settlement relating to Lehman's structured notes of $192 million which impacts 2010 costs by $95 million.

Performance metrics. Following the rights issue there are some mechanistic changes required to EPS in 2009. For clarity we have shown here the pre- and post-rights numbers, reflecting the change in the number of shares. The impact on the average weighted number of shares in 2010 is limited, because the shares were only an issue for the final six weeks of the year. Normalized EPS grew 14%. Normalized ROE is 14.1%, partly reflecting the higher level of equity capital we now carry. When reflecting on these metrics for 2011 you should bear in mind that both EPS and ROE will reflect the full dilutive impact of the new shares issued.

Balance sheet. The balance sheet continues to strengthen and is a source of competitive advantage. We continue to focus on a strong A-D ratio, with an A-D ratio in all of our major geographies under 100%. The liquid asset ratio is at 26.6%. We have some $137 billion of liquid assets. We have very low levels of refinancing maturing over the next few years, only some $6 billion until the end of 2013, and we have already prefunded most of our requirements for 2011. Both of our businesses are self-funded. Our funding base is diverse, and is continuing to grow strongly despite increasing competition.

Current Accounts and Savings Accounts, or CASA, grew by 13% or some $21 billion, with time deposits growing 21% or some $29 billion year-on-year. CASA now comprises 51% of total deposits, up from 43% some two years ago. Overall, we are continuing to attract good levels of deposits across the group, up 17% year-on-year.

Assets. Our loan book continues to be conservatively positioned and well diversified by country and by sector. Let me evidence this. We have low loan-to-value ratios on our Mortgage book, with an average of 51%, short maturity profile on our Wholesale Loan book with some two-thirds of the book under one year, and much of it significantly less than 12 months, actually between three and four months, reflecting our trade bias. Our ABS carrying value has fallen further to $2.3 billion, less than 0.5% of total group assets.

We have low exposure to commercial real estate, to leveraged loans and to level 3 assets. We have no direct exposure to sovereign debt in the more troubled economies in the eurozone, and our overall exposure to those economies is also low. Overall exposures are diversified by geography and sector, with no material concentrations. The balance sheet remains robust and well diversified.

Capital. The group's capital position has significantly strengthened during the year. We have generated very good levels of organic equity and delivered $4.3 billion of profit attributable to shareholders in 2010, while also benefiting from the appreciative currencies against the USD. In addition we raised $5.7 billion through the October rights issue and the earlier listing of Indian depository receipts in Mumbai.

Throughout the year we have had good support from capital markets, having raised over $4 billion of lower Tier 2 and senior funding in transactions that were heavily oversubscribed. RWA growth of 15% has been well controlled and is spread between the two businesses, Wholesale up 10% or $17 billion and Consumer up 27% or $14 billion. Core tier 1 is at 11.8%, tier 1 is at 14% and total capital is at 18.4%. We are very strongly capitalized, especially in light of our conservative asset profile and well positioned both to meet potential oncoming regulatory changes and at the same time protecting our ability to grow further with our customers.

Consumer banking. The repositioning of consumer banking continues to progress well, and we are seeing very good traction across a number of metrics, both financial and nonfinancial. Income was up 8% and stood at over $6 billion, a record for the business. We have seen good double-digit income growth in our high-value segments of Priority Banking, private banking and SME. Expenses increased by 13%, with the loan impairment falling 45%. Operating profit before tax is up 51% to $1.31 billion.

Balance sheet velocity has been very strong, with loans up 24% primarily in secured products and deposits up 15%. Through working closely with wholesale banking, some 32% of new CASA during the year came from payroll accounts. CASA is now 59% of deposits, up from 41% two years ago. Consumer banking remains an important source of liquidity and contributes some $26 billion of surface liquidity to the group.

Looking at consumer banking in more detail, consumer banking income saw good momentum throughout the year, with each quarter recording successive income growth. Momentum in the second half has been good, with income up 9% on the first half. The business has faced the ongoing headwind in 2010 of continued liability margin compression, which has resulted in year-on-year income drag of some $270 million.

Against 2009, liability margins were down by 16 basis points on average to 70 basis points, but since the half-year, have stabilized. In addition, asset margins have come under some pressure throughout the year as competition has increased. Asset margins were down some 24 basis points year-on-year, principally in Mortgages, Credit Cards and SME, falling overall to 285 basis points on average. Expenses have increased by 13%. We have maintained cost discipline with business as usual costs up only some 4% year-on-year.

We also consciously took the decision to invest at pace through 2010 to drive future income momentum. We have added over 4,000 staff; within this we have added 800 relationship managers, primarily in the priority banking segment, but also in SME and in private banking and we have also added another 1,200 sales staff. These head count increases have been particularly focused on Singapore, Indonesia, China and Malaysia.

We have significantly increased marketing spend, up some 27%. We've added some 70 branches in markets including Korea, Indonesia, China, Malaysia, Bangladesh and Taiwan, and also 23 priority banking hubs. We've added over 300 ATMs, upgraded 500 ATMs, installed 80 express banking centers and expanded online and mobile banking to 29 and 32 markets respectively. As to risk, we have continued to focus on secured assets, whilst also selectively growing the unsecured loan book by some $2.4 billion. 85% of the loan book is either fully or partially secured and only 15% is unsecured. Partially reflecting this profile the consumer banking loan impairment charge has decreased to $578 million, down 45% on 2009.

Looking at income in more detail, when looking at these slides it's important to note that overall margins for the group have reduced only slightly year-on-year and what these slides give you is a sense of some of the moving parts in the group margin position. Mortgage income was up 22% against 2009, with a strong increase in loans of some 23%; this more than offset margin compression of 13 basis points to 132 basis points on average in the retail mortgage book.

Market shares remain strong in our large mortgage markets. We've seen continued good growth in deposits, especially CASA, but the ongoing low-interest rate environment has resulted in deposit income falling 8% on 2009. Liability margins stabilized in the second half of the year and income in the second half was therefore up 11% on the first half, reflecting deposit growth.

Wealth Management fee income led by funds and treasury products was up 24% year-on-year and has now grown for four halves in succession. Wealth Management income in the fourth quarter of 2010 was at record levels with fund sales in Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore particularly strong. This momentum has continued into 2011.

Moving to Credit Cards, income in Credit Cards and Personal Loans, or CCPL, was up 3% and balances up 17% on 2009, driven by selected asset growth in markets such as Hong Kong, Korea, Singapore and Malaysia. We continue to position our product offering towards customers in our target segments with a bias to transactors resulting in lower overall margins.

SME income is up 14% year-on-year to some $1.2 billion and up 6% in the second half on the first half driven by particularly good growth in trade products, associated FX transactions and in cash management. Both sides of the balance sheet have grown well, with SME loans up 32% and SME deposits up 23% in 2010. This business has strong momentum as we continue to increase lending to our SME customers.

Impairment. Loan impairment has shown significant improvement with the portfolio loss rate well under half of the rates seen in the prior year. Looking by product, you will see that this is a consistent picture.

In mortgages, loan impairment has fallen significantly and the loss rate in 2010 was 7 basis points across the portfolio. Within SME, loan impairment is roughly halved year-on-year with loss rates sharply down. We have de-risked the SME book and are still benefiting from some $2.7 billion of loans under government-guarantee schemes. Cards and Personal Loans contribute some $16 billion of the total $29 billion of other loans, with the balance being Secured Private Bank and Wealth Management lending. The vast majority of the $425 million loan impairment in other loans was driven by the CCPL portfolio.

Loss rates are down by around a half since 2009, reflecting a stronger risk profile but also improving macroeconomic conditions across our markets. The total loss rate across all products was 53 basis points, the lowest loss rate we have seen for a decade. Our forward indicators are steady and showing no signs of deterioration.

Loan impairment is sharply down and we have a robust cover ratio of 82%. When thinking about the outlook for impairment, there are two factors to bear in mind. Firstly, we intend to continue growing unsecured in a disciplined manner in selected markets, so a mix change, and secondly we are positioned to continue to see good overall loan growth, albeit probably at lower levels than in 2010.

To summarize for consumer banking overall, continuing steady income momentum built on excellent balance sheet growth and activity levels. Assets continue to show a bias towards secured, and liabilities continue to grow. We have invested further in our distribution network, in the sales force and in the brand, and this positions us very well for 2011.

Wholesale banking. Wholesale banking has delivered a strong performance during 2010, and has continued to focus on deepening client relationships. Wholesale banking income was up 7%, with good double-digit client income growth, up 17%, partially offset by moderating own-account income down 19%. Through whichever lens you look, client income remains strong.

Corporate Finance up 32%, Trade up 14%, Financial Markets up 18%, Capital Markets up 32%. We continue to be disciplined in managing the relationship between RWA and Client Income growth. Client income grew 17% on 2009, whereas RWA grew by 10%. Loan impairment has fallen sharply, down 68% on 2009. Expenses rose 16%, driven by a number of factors.

A little over 40% of the increase in expenses relates to BAU costs, including the modest impact of increased variable pay. 15% relates to the impact of FX, and we have also seen the impact of higher regulatory and compliance spend. Just under one-quarter of the increase relates to investments, both the flow through from 2009 and incremental investment made in 2010. We have focused investment in 2010 on three themes.

Firstly, the build out of product capability in Financial Markets and Transaction Banking, which accounted for half of the 2010 investment spend. We have added head count and invested in particular in eCommerce, cash equities, integrating our Custody business in Africa and the further build out of our trade finance system, Magellan across the bank.

Secondly, in enhancing sales coverage, with a focus on SCCG, adding almost 200 people. Strategic Client Coverage Group is particularly important for our strategic and value-add products, and is a key driver of the Wholesale business, with income up 27% year-on-year.

Third, infrastructure and people investment, accounting for one-quarter of 2010 investment spend, covering operations, support and control functions and risk management, where we have added over 300 head count. As a result, jaws were a negative 9% in 2010, although on a two-year basis jaws are 2% positive.

Income. Income by client segment remains well spread with three out of four of the client segments generating income in excess of $2 billion. By product, Lending and Portfolio Management income grew 2% and Transaction Banking income was up 9%, Global Markets was up 7%.

Looking at income in more detail, lending income was up from $849 million to $868 million, as average assets increased 8% and margins fell slightly. In Trade, income was up 14%, driven by assets and contingents up 28%. Activity levels are sharply higher with the number of Trade LCs issued up 20% year-on-year. Margins, at an average of 135 basis points, were down some 37 basis points year-on-year.

Cash saw a very strong increase in average balances, up 21%, as transaction levels rose strongly. Despite average margins falling some 15 basis points on 2009, Cash Management income was up 4% year-on-year. The compression in margins has resulted in year-on-year income drag of some $120 million. I will touch on financial markets on the next slide. ALM income as we indicated was down 5% year-on-year and down as expected, 13% half on half, as maturing positions have been reinvested at lower rates.

Corporate Finance income of $1.7 billion was up 32%, reflecting steady investment in products and people over recent years. In 2010 we closed 65% more deals than in 2009. Income is increasingly well diversified by geography and pipelines are strong as we enter 2011. Principal Finance income of $416 million is up 23% year-on-year; this is a business where we continue to invest selectively and one where we also continue to see good levels of realizations.

Also Banking continues to be a Client Income led business. Year-on-year Client Income has increased its share of total income from 74% to 80% and has shown good double-digit growth. We continue to see Client Income momentum, up 3% on the preceding quarter and we finished the year strongly, so fourth quarter was up marginally on the third quarter.

Looking at Financial Markets in more detail, income in Financial Markets of $3.3 billion was flat on 2009, albeit within that total, Client Income grew strongly at 18%. Own Account income was down 40%, reflecting tighter spreads despite higher numbers of transactions as volatility trended lower during the year. In FX and rates the impact of spread compression more than offset good volume growth, resulting in income falling 11% in FX and 5% in rates. Capital Markets, where income increased 32% to $541 million, saw excellent deal flow in 2010 and continuing strong lead table positions.

Loan impairment. Wholesale Bank loan impairment was $305 million, down 68% on 2009. The overall quality of the portfolio has continued to show steady improvement throughout the year, and the number and quantum of early alerts have continued to improve throughout 2010 and are not showing any particular industry or geographic concentration. The wholesale banking cover ratio has reduced to 50%. This results from the inclusion of a small number of accounts in the Middle East, which have been classified as non-performing, and which are subject to either existing or near-completed restructuring agreements. Excluding the impact of these accounts, and including the impact of collateral, the cover ratio is in excess of 70%, well within our historic recovery rates of well over 40%.

Let me summarize the overall wholesale banking picture. Wholesale banking has delivered another strong set of results, with record levels of client income arising from multiple engines. It is invested for the future. Its forward-risk indicators are stable at improved levels. It enters 2011 with strong transaction pipelines, significantly higher activity levels, and with good growth in customer assets and cash balances.

Geographic performance. Let me touch just on a couple of these geographies, and Peter will pick up some of the others. Korea's profit was up 20% year-on-year on a headline basis, driven as guided by a materially stronger second half performance, with second half profit up 60% on the first half. Despite this, margin pressure persists, competition in increasing, and our cost income ratio remains too high. There is much we still need to do to improve returns in Korea.

Within other APR, profit was up $313 million, with the main driver being Taiwan. Profits in Taiwan increased to $238 million from the loss of $11 million in 2009, driven by a significant fall in expenses given the non-recurrence of the $170 million charge associated with the buyback of some structured notes in 2009. This is a strong business, which has now been effectively repositioned, its cost base addressed, its asset portfolio de-risked and is well placed to become an increasingly important source of steady growth for the group.

Profit in MESA more than doubled year-on-year, benefiting from a significant reduction of $509 million in loan impairment. The UAE is the largest geography in MESA, contributing around half of income and accounting for around 60% of the loan book. In the UAE we have de-risked our consumer banking loan book and our Wholesale loan book remains short tenure and well spread.

Profit in Africa was up 16% on income up 14%. Africa is an increasingly diverse region with six markets delivering over $100 million of income. In 2010 our 26 branch network in Nigeria delivered over $200 million of income for the first time.

Profit in the Americas, U.K. and Europe region was down 38%. This reflects the impact of the gain on the buyback of some of our tier 2 paper, which was booked in 2009 and did not recur in 2010 and also falling loan impairment. This geographical segment remains a key origination center for the group.

Turning then to outlook, we start 2011 strongly with the balance sheet in excellent shape. This robust platform provides a foundation for further well-controlled growth in both assets and liabilities. And we enter the year with good momentum and with volume growth in both businesses. We have had a record January, both in terms of income and profit; and you will recall that we started quickly in 2010. In wholesale banking, Client Income remains strong, ahead of last January and in line with the general trend of it contributing around three-quarters of total income. Our deal pipelines remain very good.

In consumer banking the balance sheet has good velocity and we have invested for growth. We have seen continued steady income progress in the first month and start 2011 without the significant drag of liability margin pressure. Our forward-looking risk indicators remain steady, however we are watchful of asset and consumer price inflation and the policy implications this may trigger. We expect continued competitive pressures as the attractiveness of our markets has not gone unnoticed by our peers. Regulatory change will continue to be the biggest external risk to our performance.

With this in mind, what should you expect for 2011? Given the markets we are in and the momentum of our businesses, we believe we can continue to deliver double-digit growth in income in 2011 and beyond. Excluding the impact of the bank levy, we are also managing the business to bring income and cost growth back in line for the full year 2011. We are keeping a firm grip on expenses in both businesses, and look forward to seeing further income benefit on the investments made in 2009 and 2010.

For earnings and return on equity, you should consider both the full year impact of the rights issue, and secondly you should consider the significant impact of the bank levy. Similar to past years, we will remain focused on the fundamentals of the group, which are in excellent shape. We have a very strong liquid and conservative balance sheet, we are very strongly capitalized, we are well positioned in growth markets, we continue to take market share in multiple products and across multiple geographies.
Thank you and now I'll hand over to Peter.

Thank you, Richard. Good morning and good afternoon to those of you in Hong Kong and India. These results represent our eighth consecutive year of record income and profits. This is not a story of a bounce back or a recovery, but one of consistent delivery of diverse and sustained growth. 23 of our markets now deliver over $100 million of income, 15 over $100 million in profit. We are extraordinarily well placed in the world's most attractive markets, we are investing in both our businesses, Wholesale and Consumer, winning market share, growing income and profits, creating value for our shareholders.

Much of what drives the Standard Chartered story remains constant. We have refreshed our one-page statement of strategic intent, but actually our strategic aspiration remains unchanged. We want to be the world's best international bank, leading the way in Asia, Africa and the Middle East. We are putting even greater focus on our clients and customers, on building deep, longstanding relationships, on the quality of our service and solutions. We continue to be obsessed with the basics of banking, balancing the pursuit of growth with disciplined management of costs and risks, keeping a firm grip on liquidity and capital. And we continue to focus on culture and values, on the way we work together across multiple geographies, products and segments, combining deep local knowledge with global capability.

These fundamentals underscore everything the bank does and everything we, as a bank, stand for. I have no doubt that the clarity and consistency of our strategy are disciplined in sticking to it and our distinctive culture and values have been crucial to our continued success. But it would be a mistake to think this means we haven't changed at all. Standard Chartered today is very different from the bank I joined in early 2002.

We entered that year having made a little over $1 billion in pre-tax profits the year before with a share price of £6.92, some 28,000 staff and under constant threat of takeover. Now in 2010, we had two individual markets, India and Hong Kong delivering profits equal to what the entire group made in 2001, around 85,000 staff and our shareholders have seen a total shareholder return of over 230% from the end of 2001 to the end of 2010.

While our story remains consistent, the bank has continued to evolve rapidly during 2010. One of the most visible changes was the launch of Here for Good, our brand promise, in April. Here for Good is not just a catchy phrase, it captures the essence of who we are. We're a bank that sticks by its clients and customers, through good times and bad. We're a bank that always strives to do the right thing. Our job is to create value for our shareholders, but we're also committed to having a positive impact on the broader economy and on the communities in which we live and work.

Here for Good had resonated with staff, with clients and customers and with other stakeholders, because it's true, because it's simple, and because it's powerful. We know we've set a benchmark that people will hold us to, but that's the point. One example of where we are hitting the sweet spot of delivering for our shareholders and making a positive impact on the broader economy is SME banking. We continued to increase our lending to SMEs throughout the crisis, up 14% in 2009 and by 32%, or just over $4 billion, in 2010. In fact we have increased total lending to our clients and customers by $90 billion, some 60% since the start of the crisis in mid-2007.

To give you a sense of how we're changing the bank without altering the fundamentals, I want to talk a bit about some of our key markets and also about how we're using technology to change the way we run the bank and interact with our clients and customers.

You'll recall that in 2009 Hong Kong just pipped India to be our most profitable market. And this time last year I suggested there was a bit of a race between the two as to which would become our most profitable market in 2010. Well, India won, a great achievement and a great story of investing in organic growth. Building on the platform we created with the acquisition of Grindlays, we have grown profits from a combined figure of $110 million in 2000 to $1.2 billion in 2010, a CAGR cumulative average growth rate of 27%. Last year income in India was over $2 billion for the first time, up 12% on 2009.

We can't expect India to grow at quite the same pace it has in recent years, given the sheer scale of the business, but it's still going to be one of the group's big growth engines so we're continuing to invest in new product capabilities such as equities, new segments such as private banking and expanded infrastructure such as our express banking centers.

The launch of our IDR in Mumbai, the first listing by an international company in India, was a powerful statement of our commitment. It also proved a very effective way to build the brand. Brand awareness among our target segments has registered sharp increases during 2010.

Looking forward, the Indian economy continues to grow at pace and we continue to see huge opportunities. Extending our distribution reach beyond our current total of 94 branches is a key priority, particularly for consumer banking and in this context we are considering carefully the potential benefits from subsidiarization suggested in the RBI's recent consultation paper.

But our India team can't rest on their laurels. Not least because we are seeing an acceleration of growth in Hong Kong as the economic dynamics of greater China become ever more powerful. Whilst mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan are very different as markets given distinct regulatory systems and very different competitive dynamics, the links between these economies are developing extraordinarily rapidly, and this is having a profound impact on trade and capital flows. We want to ensure we don't just seize the opportunities the individual markets present but grab the greater China opportunity, helping companies and individuals across the region to trade and invest, find partners, do deals.

One fact illustrates the pace of these developments. Direct flights between China and Taiwan were first permitted in July, 2008. I was on one of those first flights. Today there are nearly 400 direct flights per week. Whilst we have made great progress in Taiwan, as Richard has already described, we've only just begun to scratch the cross-straits opportunity.

The Greater China dynamic is also having a powerful impact on Hong Kong. This is a market, which it might be tempting to write off as ex-growth or at least mature for us, but this would be a mistake. We think Hong Kong offers significant opportunities for growth, as its role evolves as China's international financial center. Take for example what's happening with the internationalization of the renminbi. In 2009 virtually none of China's trade transactions were settled in renminbi. In 2010 it was over $75 billion worth, mostly in Hong Kong.

Settling trade transactions in renminbi is generating offshore renminbi deposits, which grew five-fold during 2010 to around $48 billion equivalent and another $10 billion in January alone, and this in turn is enabling the creation of an offshore renminbi bond market, the Dim Sum market. We foresaw those developments and anticipate further exponential growth. We were the first bank to facilitate a domestic renminbi trade settlement, the first to launch a renminbi-denominated bond for foreign corporate, and the first to offer retail renminbi structured products. Our renminbi deposits in Hong Kong grew 10-fold in 2010.

This is just one example of how dramatically China is impacting Hong Kong. Every aspect of the business, including consumer banking, is feeling the effects of China's transformation. Our Hong Kong business accelerated in the second half of 2010 with income up 13% on the first half and with a record fourth quarter. Our India team cannot afford to be at all complacent.

Singapore is another market that is sometimes seen as one of our more mature businesses, but it's also one where we see significant growth opportunities. Singapore is successfully building its position as an international financial center, and we are playing a significant role in this development. We run both our businesses from Singapore, and many of our key functions such as technology and operations are centered there.

In January we opened our new office in the Marina Bay Financial Centre development, the first company to move in. This building, which accommodates about 4,500 people, has a trading floor with 790 positions across 65,000 square feet. We believe it's the largest trading floor in Asia. Singapore is also the main hub of our private banking business. From a greenfield start in 2006 and with the benefit of the AB acquisition in 2007, private banking now has $46 billion AUM, up 31% on 2009. It's been less than five years since we opened for business and we're already the sixth largest private bank in Asia.

Singapore is also a good example of a market where we have carried out selected acquisitions to boost our product capability. Last year we acquired a factoring business to support our SME clients and earlier this year we acquired an auto finance business.

Just next door to Singapore is a market which we believe is too often underestimated, Indonesia. The largest economy in Southeast Asia, the fourth largest population in the world, a country rich in resources, underpinned by a stable political environment, good fiscal policy and strong currency. We regard Indonesia as one of the fast-growth 7% club countries over the next 20 years, likely to become the fifth largest economy in the world by 2030.

We are in a strong position to take advantage of Indonesia's potential both through our own business and via our 45% stake in PermataBank. Standard Chartered in Indonesia has 26 branches, Permata has 280. With different strengths and distinct target segments, these complementary franchises enable us to seize the multiple growth opportunities the country's economic momentum presents. Indonesia contributed just under $200 million to group pre-tax profits in 2010 and we see significant potential for further growth over the medium term.

By telling you a bit about some of our key markets, I hope I have given you a flavor of what we've been doing and what lies ahead, but I also want to highlight the way we're using technology to enhance efficiency and improve our service. We have fundamentally transformed the infrastructure of the bank over the last few years, giving us far greater scalability and resilience and a much stronger platform for innovation. By standardizing systems platforms, re-engineering processes and hubbing activity into our principal shared services centers in Chennai, KL and Tianjin, we've been able to drive down technology and operations running costs as a percentage of income from just over 12% in 2004 to just under 8% last year. Platforms like Magellan, our trade finance system, are enabling us to achieve continuous improvement in unit transaction costs.

Given the pace of underlying volume growth across so many of our businesses, for example, Trade LC's up 20% year-on-year, FX transactions up 14%, commodities transactions up 66%, such scalability is absolutely vital.

We're now also much more innovative in our use of technology to interact with clients. Last year we launched Breeze, an innovative iPhone banking app, in Singapore and Malaysia that allows you access your accounts, pay bills, transfer money, find ATMs and credit cards offers in an intuitive and easy way. In October we launched Straight2Bank for the iPad, the world's first app for trade finance, enabling clients to authorize payments, make transactions and approve or revise documents on the go.

Banking is intrinsically digital and like other digital industries it can be transformed through technology. We can turn siloed products into integrated solutions. We can empower our clients and customers by putting tools and information into their hands. We can achieve radical improvements in processing times and costs.

So what about the challenges? Where do I see the potential obstacles or things that could knock us off course? Within the bank, the main challenge is execution. I think we've got the strategy, we know what we've got to do as a group and within the two businesses, but making it happen at pace is a big complex agenda and there are a lot of external distractions. We need to keep very focused on the key priorities, these are very clear.

We must maintain our track record of delivery, sustaining the momentum in wholesale banking and completing the transformation of consumer banking. We must deepen our relationships with our clients and customers. We must keep focused on the basics of banking: liquidity, capital, risk and cost discipline. Aand we must continue to reinforce our brand.

Clearly, we need to continue managing costs very tightly, prioritizing investment and delivering continuous improvement in productivity. The trick here is to strike the right balance, investing to ensure we grasp the longer-term opportunities, while ensuring we keep delivering in the near term. Jam today and jam tomorrow. But the biggest challenges we face are external and the biggest of these is regulation, put bluntly changes in regulation, policy and tax represent the biggest tax we as a bank face particularly because so much is uncoordinated or unilateral.

To give you one example, the recent announcement that the U.K. bank levy will be implemented in full in 2011 means that the levy will cost us around $180 million post-tax this year. But I'm not going to bore you by talking about regulation and taxes. I think I've already made my views clear on most of these issues anyway.

We also face challenges in some markets from political dislocation, most obviously in the Middle East and Africa and most recently in Cote d'Ivoire, where we have temporarily suspended operations. But the challenges here are more about protecting our staff and customers rather than primarily financial, given that our businesses in the most affected countries tend to be rather small.

Perhaps more fundamentally we remain relatively cautious about the outlook for the world economy this year. We're certainly in a global recovery, but it's a very polarized recovery and vulnerable to shocks. Our markets, and particularly Asia, are growing strongly and we're very positive about the longer-term outlook. However, the West still faces a deleveraging challenge, and there hasn't been that much progress on tackling global imbalances and the specter of inflation is very real in Asia and in the West. Asia is no longer dependent on the West to drive economic growth, but neither is it decoupled. Currencies, capital flows and trade mean there are powerful interdependencies.

Finally I should mention competition. Off a couple of years in which many of our competitors were in some disarray, we are seeing more competition across our markets, both from increasingly capable local banks and from international banks returning to the fray. This has had an impact in margins in some markets, but overall we're still winning market share in many markets, products and segments.

In fact, the aspect of competition that most concerns me is the war for talent. We need to be competitive in the way we reward and recognize people. We need to be able to provide them with opportunities to grow and develop, and we need to be somewhere people want to work. That's where our values and culture are a powerful source of competitive advantage and where Here for Good sets us apart.

Delivering eight years of record income and growth, sustaining our momentum throughout the crisis has taken a lot of hard work, professionalism and discipline, and I would like to take this opportunity to thank all of our staff for once again showing what we can achieve as a team.

I'd also like to thank you, our shareholders, for your support. We were delighted by the way you backed us with the rights issue last October with 98.5% taking up your rights. We now have the capital to absorb the regulatory requirements and to continue to grow at pace. Indeed the strength of our capital position combined with the depth of our liquidity and the diversity of our assets gives us a balance sheet that is a powerful source of competitive advantage.

We start 2011 confident, but far from complacent. We're excited by the multitude of opportunities in our markets, but we are alert to the near-term risks. We've been investing to take advantage of the opportunities, but we will flex our costs and balance sheet as events unfold. The bank enters 2011 in great shape.

We have a clear strategy which we will stick to. We have an increasingly powerful brand. We have an exceptionally strong balance sheet, both our businesses have good momentum and have begun the year well.
